column1: Sarasota () is a city in Sarasota County on the southwestern coast of the U.S. state of Florida. The area is renowned for its cultural and environmental amenities
column3: resorts
column4: and the Sarasota School of Architecture. The city is at the southern end of the Tampa Bay Area
column5: north of Fort Myers and Punta Gorda. Its official limits include Sarasota Bay and several barrier islands between the bay and the Gulf of Mexico. According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column6: in 2019 Sarasota had a population of 58
column7: 285. In 1986 it became designated as a certified local government. Sarasota is a principal city of the Sarasota metropolitan area
column8: and is the seat of Sarasota County.  Long the winter headquarters of the Ringling Brothers Circus
column9: many landmarks in Sarasota are named for the Ringlings.

column1: Longboat Key is the largest key separating the bay from the gulf
column2: but it was evenly divided by the new county line of 1921. The portion of the key that parallels the Sarasota city boundary that extends to that new county line along the bay front of the mainland was removed from the city boundaries at the request of John Ringling in the mid-1920s
column3: who sought to avoid city taxation of his planned developments at the southern tip of the key. Although they never were completed in the quickly faltering economy
column4: those development concessions granted by the city never were reversed and the county has retained regulation of those lands.

column1: The city limits had expanded significantly with the real estate rush of the early twentieth century
column2: reaching almost 70 square miles (180 km2). The wild speculation boom began to crash in 1926 and following that
column3: the city limits began to contract
column4: shrinking to less than a quarter of that area.

column1: The area known today as Sarasota first appeared on a sheepskin Spanish map from 1763 with the word Zarazote over present day Sarasota and Bradenton. The municipal government of Sarasota was established when it was incorporated as a town in 1902.

column2: the city has a total area of 25.9 square miles (67 km2)
column3: of which 14.9 sq mi (38.6 km2) is land and 11.0 sq mi (28 km2) is water.

column1: Sarasota has a humid subtropical climate closely bordering a tropical savanna climate
column3: humid summers
column4: and warm
column5: dry winters. There are distinct rainy and dry seasons
column6: with the rainy season lasting from June to September
column7: and the dry season from October to May. The most recent officially recorded freezes in Sarasota took place on January 18
column9: when the temperature dropped to 30 °F (−1 °C) at the Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport. However
column10: Sarasota averages less than one frost annually.

column1: Sarasota municipal government was last incorporated in 1913
column2: changing from a town type to adopting the city type of local government found in the United States and the title of its government changed to "City of Sarasota". Sarasota later was designated as the county seat when Sarasota County was carved out of Manatee County in 1921 during the creation of several new counties. In 1945 the commission-manager government form was adopted for the city and it is governed by a five-person commission elected by popular vote
column3: two members of which serve in the ceremonial positions of "mayor" and "vice-mayor"
column4: as chosen by the commission every April. Two at-large commissioners are elected by all voters and the city is divided into three districts for which the residents of each elect one district representative to the five member commission.

column2: the city of Sarasota made national news when the National Coalition for the Homeless and the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty ranked it number one on the groups' list of twenty "meanest cities" in America in their published report A Dream Denied: The Criminalization of Homelessness in U.S. Cities. The city's adoption of its "no lodging out-of-doors" ordinance on August 15
column4: Ordinance No. 05-4640
column5: made it illegal to sleep outside on public property without permission
column6: as was already the case with private property. In recent years
column7: the City of Sarasota has revolutionized its approach to managing local homelessness focusing on casework
column8: mental health assessments and housing. The city has earned a national
column9: state and regional recognition for its efforts.

column1: Sarasota is among the communities included in a two-county federally mandated Metropolitan Planning Organization that includes all of Sarasota and Manatee counties and the chairs of the three elements of that organization belong to the eight-county regional planning organization for western central Florida.

column4: who created the first street painting that changed images from day to night. The festival has a different theme each year and has introduced new techniques in street art. column1: Italian architecture and culture are quite strong in the area because of the Ringling Museum. An unusually large number of homes and buildings are designed in the Italian style
column2: especially Venetian as influenced by Ringling's Cà d'Zan. Italian inspired statues are also common and Michelangelo's David is used as the symbol of Sarasota.

column1: The Sarasota School of Architecture developed as a variant of mid-century modernist architecture. It incorporates elements of both the Bauhaus and Frank Lloyd Wright's "organic" architecture. The style developed as an adaptation to the area's sub-tropical climate and used newly emerging materials manufactured or implemented following World War II.
By the end of the twentieth century
column2: many of Sarasota's more modest historical structures were demolished. Recently
column3: two historic buildings
column4: the Crocker Church and the Bidwell-Wood House (the oldest remaining structure in the city)
column5: first restored by Veronica Morgan and members of the Sarasota Alliance for Historic Preservation that she founded
column6: became city property. These structures were relocated to this park
column7: despite protests from residents who objected to the loss of park area.

column2: Sarasota County purchased the Terrace Hotel that was built by Charles Ringling and renovated it for use as a county government office building. The adjacent courthouse that he donated to the new county in 1921 has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The courthouse complex was designed by Dwight James Baum.

column1: Many significant structures from the comparatively recent "Sarasota School of Architecture" period of the mid-twentieth century
column3: have not survived. Since they do not qualify under the age criteria set for historic preservation nominations their historical aspect often escapes public recognition. Others frequently are threatened by demolition plans for new development without consideration of their cultural and historical importance to the community instead of motivating the implementation of plans to retain the buildings and integrate them into new plans.

column1: The major airport in the area is Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport which is shared by Sarasota and Manatee counties. It has since being opened in 1941 the areas major airport. Before this
column2: Lowe's Field functioned as the main airport for the Sarasota Area from 1929–1941. Five airlines offer service out of the airport to locations primarily in the United States and Canada. The airport serves more than 1
column4: 000 passengers per year. The airport holds full port of entry status providing U.S. Customs inspections for international travelers. St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport and Tampa International Airport are located about an hour north from Sarasota
column5: and Southwest Florida International Airport in Ft. Myers an hour and 45 min south of Sarasota. All 3 offer a wider range of national and international flights.

column1: A key issue is providing Sarasota with access to the Florida High Speed Rail. The Seaboard Coast Line ran intercity train service to the city until 1971. There is no Amtrak train which stops in Sarasota

column3: located approximately 2 miles (3.2 km) from the city limits of Sarasota
column4: to the nearest Amtrak terminal in Tampa. A freight-only rail line operated by Seminole Gulf Railway does serve industries in Sarasota.

column1: As a city located on the Gulf of Mexico
column2: water transportation is a key consideration. The Intracoastal Waterway is a 3
column3: 000-mile (4
column4: 800 km) waterway providing water access to and from the Atlantic coast for tugs
column5: barges and leisure boats. Port Manatee and the Port of Tampa both provide nearby deep water ports. Port Manatee provides cargo service primarily while the Port of Tampa is more diverse. Port Manatee formerly even had a cruise line
column6: Regal Cruise Line that operated out of in from 1993–2003 until it was seized by U.S Marshals on April 18
column7: 2003 for not being maintained. The waterway enters Sarasota Bay which provides access to downtown Sarasota at the city pier.

column1: Because of its location on the Gulf of Mexico and its proximity to several other large metropolitan areas
column2: road transportation is critical to the Sarasota area. The major roads in the area include:

column1: I-75 – The only freeway in the area
column2: I-75 is located 5 miles from the center of town and is a major interstate leading south to Miami and north to Tampa.

column1: U.S. 41 Tamiami Trail – A major north–south route through Sarasota enters central Sarasota from the south before heading west at the south end of U.S. 301. After briefly following Bayfront Drive the Trail heads north again paralleling the coast.
U.S. 301 – Heading north from its intersection with U.S. 41
column2: U.S. 301 follows Washington Boulevard running parallel to U.S. 41 and Interstate 75.

column1: SR 780 – 3rd Street/Fruitville Road – A main east/west throughway linking U.S. 41
column3: and Interstate 75.

column1: SR 789 – Starts out as John Ringling Causeway before heading to Bird Key and Lido Key
